images.copyright: Light decorations on Spiegelgracht canal, Amsterdam, Netherlands (© Amith Nag Photography/Getty Images)
images.title: Still waters, bright lights
images.caption: Spiegelgracht canal in Amsterdam, Netherlands
images.desc: Have you ever wondered how canals changed the way cities developed? For thousands of years, people have built canals to transport goods, control water flow and connect places. From ancient Mesopotamia and Egypt to medieval Europe, they transformed cities like Venice and Bruges into trade hubs. The Netherlands took this even further—by the 17th century, they were designing waterways that shaped cities such as Amsterdam.

og.title: Spiegelgracht canal in Amsterdam, Netherlands
og.desc: Have you ever wondered how canals changed the way cities developed? For thousands of years, people have built canals to transport goods…

images.title: A silent force in India's wilderness
images.caption: Royal Bengal tiger
images.desc: Tigers reshape the landscape without being seen. A single presence, and the forest rearranges itself around it. The Royal Bengal tiger moves through India's forests, grasslands and mangrove swamps with a quiet authority that no other predator matches. It hunts with patience, not spectacle, using scent marks, sharpened senses and near-perfect night vision to stalk deer and wild boar. When it strikes, it does so with a finality that explains why no other creature in the wild dares contest its ground.
images.bsTitle: A silent force in India's wilderness

images.copyright: Merced River, Yosemite National Park, California, United States (© Ron and Patty Thomas/Getty Images)
images.title: Frozen reflections
images.caption: Merced River, Yosemite National Park, California, United States
images.desc: Every masterpiece needs a brushstroke to tie it together. For Yosemite National Park, that stroke is the Merced River—painting reflections of granite cliffs, pine forests and waterfalls across its canvas. One of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers, this waterway begins high in the Sierra Nevada. It gathers meltwater and travels about 235 kilometres west through Yosemite Valley into California's Central Valley in the United States.

og.title: Merced River, Yosemite National Park, California, United States
og.desc: Every masterpiece needs a brushstroke to tie it together. For Yosemite National Park, that stroke is the Merced River—painting reflections…

images.title: The plant that paints the holidays red
images.caption: Poinsettia: A winter classic
images.desc: Some plants simply sit quietly on windowsills. The poinsettia? It demands the spotlight — bright, bold and as red as Rudolph's nose. Long before it became a popular Christmas decoration, it grew wild in Mexico, where the Aztecs used its leaves for dyes and its sap for traditional remedies. In the 19th century, it travelled across continents as people admired its vivid colour during colder months, eventually finding its place in winter celebrations around the world.
images.bsTitle: The plant that paints the holidays red

og.title: Poinsettia: A winter classic

images.copyright: The summit of Mount Everest at sunset, seen from Renjo La, Nepal (© shoults/Alamy)
images.title: Where the sky meets Earth
images.caption: International Mountain Day
images.desc: Every 11 December, we celebrate International Mountain Day, honouring the majestic peaks that shape our planet and the glaciers that support life. From the rolling Alps to the towering Himalayas, mountains cover nearly a quarter of Earth's land and host 15% of the world's population and nearly half of its biodiversity hotspots. Mount Everest, the world's highest peak at over 8845 metres, stands as a symbol of human aspiration and natural beauty. Its glaciers feed rivers sustaining millions, showing that mountains are more than scenery—they are lifelines.

og.title: International Mountain Day
og.desc: Every 11 December, we celebrate International Mountain Day, honouring the majestic peaks that shape our planet and the glaciers that support…

images.copyright: Interior of the Mosque-Cathedral of Córdoba, Andalusia, Spain (© Elena Zolotova/Getty Images)
images.title: Where cultures converge
images.caption: Mosque-Cathedral of Córdoba, Andalusia, Spain
images.desc: The Mosque-Cathedral of Córdoba is a chronicle of Spain's layered history. It began as a church built by the Germanic Visigoths, before being transformed into a mosque in 784 CE by Abd al-Rahman I, founder of the Umayyad Emirate of Córdoba. Its vast hypostyle hall, a space supported by rows of columns, features the famous red-and-white arches shown here. Today, it contains more than 850 columns, many reused from Roman and earlier Visigothic structures.

og.title: Mosque-Cathedral of Córdoba, Andalusia, Spain
og.desc: The Mosque-Cathedral of Córdoba is a chronicle of Spain's layered history. It began as a church built by the Germanic Visigoths, before…

images.copyright: Guanaco, Punta Norte, Valdés Peninsula, Argentina (© Sylvain Cordier/naturepl.com)
images.title: Say 'cheese'… or grass
images.caption: Guanaco, Punta Norte, Valdés Peninsula, Argentina
images.desc: If llamas are the laid-back stars of the Andes, their cousins, the guanacos, are the free spirits of Patagonia. Guanacos are part of the same camelid family as llamas, alpacas and vicuñas. But unlike their domesticated relatives, they keep things wild. Found mainly in Argentina, Chile, Peru and Bolivia, they're built for life at high altitude. Their thick coats help them handle chilly winds, while their padded feet give them the grip to trek across rocky terrain that would make even mountain goats nervous.

og.desc: If llamas are the laid-back stars of the Andes, their cousins, the guanacos, are the free spirits of Patagonia. Guanacos are part of the…

images.copyright: Christmas lights on buildings of Domaso, Lake Como, Italy (© Roberto Moiola/Getty Images)
images.title: All is calm, all is bright
images.caption: Christmas lights on buildings of Domaso, Lake Como, Italy
images.desc: When the twinkling reflections on Italy's Lake Como outshine the stars, you know Christmas has docked in Domaso. Once a fishing village, this lakeside town now transforms each winter into a glittering display of holiday cheer, where pastel houses, old churches and waterfront villas are wrapped in ribbons of light. The result? A picturesque Christmas scene.
images.bsTitle: All is calm, all is bright
